text:
Michael... I think you should know we don't have just one study demonstrating that climate change is occurring due to human sources, but thousands, possibly millions. We also have predictions. Tons of them. There are studies that have accurately predicted the temperature increases in the troposphere and decreases in the stratosphere due to greenhouse gas emissions. We have studies accurately quantifying the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere, a major feedback to CO2 warming. We have studies quantifying and predicting ice loss in both polar regions and in mountain glaciers. We have studies quantifying the amount of heat stored in the ocean as well as the uptake of CO2, a major cause of decreases in ocean oxygen content and ocean acidification, respectively. We even have studies demonstrating predicting that CO2 does act as a "greening" agent for plant biomass, although that effect will likely diminish in the future and has some negative effect such as reduced nutrient concentration in food plants.

If you can think of it, some scientist has likely made an entire career of studying it. It's a shame you don't think climatology or atmospheric science isn't interesting enough to read about. I'm sure if you did, you'd be more worried, and would have some free-market or conservative solutions to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels while continuing economic prosperity.

text:
The Little Ice Age,  and the previous Medieval warm period, were mostly localized to the Northern Hemisphere and the rate of change was relatively small. Compare that to today, where the warming is global and the changes are several orders of magnitude faster than at any point in the last ~10,000 years. In fact, to find changes even approaching todays, you have to go to the deglaciation phase during the last Ice Age, and even those changes occurred 10 times slower than what we see today.

The issue isn't necessarily whether temperatures were warmer in the past, although it's almost certain that current global temperatures are warmer than they have been in about 250,000 years or so. The biggest issue is the rate of these changes and the stresses they'll put on the ecosystem services human civilization requires to thrive.

author: Slim Moses

text:
At this point we are beyond the need to make predictions of things happening to see the consequences of anthropogenic climate change. We can simply look at what has happened recently.

Nearly every year in the past decade in the US has been the hottest on record. It's not so much that the hottest days are hotter - it's that we get more of them. This has caused issues with water shortages, decreased crop yields, etc.

Both the frequency and intensity of hurricanes and tropical storms have increased. The storms do more damage and we get more of them on average.

These are fairly easy problems to project into the future. The exact time it will take is uncertain, but temperatures will continue to rise. We will continue to lose farmland and coastal areas will continue to be damaged. The most hyperbolic, fearmongering predictions of disaster are wrong because that sort of thing is always wrong, but there are already visible problems and reason to believe they will get worse.

As for the "are we causing it" question: yes. It's fairly simple to get an estimate of the total carbon dioxide released each year from burning fossil fuels. The history of how much CO2 has been in the atmosphere is also well understood via things like ice core samples going back hundreds of thousands of years. We are releasing CO2 at a speed and quantity that has literally never happened before. The only time we know of that this much was released (by a massive volcano complex) it took thousands of years to release the same amount of CO2 as we have in 150 years.

So yes, the Earth gets warmer and cooler, but in all the historic data we have it has never gotten this much warmer this fast, and there's no sign of it slowing down.

text: I'm a geologist.  My dissertation research addressed matters tangentially related to climate change in the post-Wisconsinan glacial epoch (Holocene), but that was a few decades ago.  What I have noticed in the years since I completed my doctoral program is that a great many geoscience graduate students have become "true believers" in anthropogenic climate-change dogma, rather than skeptical inquirers into the matter.  They've read a good many papers and digested what they've read, but they've not done any real research on the Holocene and they've not learned how to question what they've been fed.  The young man in this video is but one of many who have never learned how to apply the scientific method to hypotheses such as anthropogenic global warming/climate change.  They are more concerned with presenting arguments that support their preferred conclusion, rather than challenging the hypotheses they have accepted uncritically.

text: As a geologist, he should know that there is no correlation between CO2 and temperature. There have been times when CO2 was more than 10x current level, yet there was ice at the equator, at sea level 20km thick. There have been times when CO2 was lower than now but temperatures were significantly warmer. Over the past ten thousand years, more than nine thousand of them have been hotter than now. One thousand years ago was the Medieval Warm Period when the Vikings were farming in Greenland (+5/6oC warmer) where they grew wheat, barley, raised cattle and grew grapes in Newfoundland. 2,000 years ago was the Roman Warm Period when citrus trees were grown in Northern England. 3,500 years ago was the Minoan Warm Period when Scandinavia had a subtropical climate. Both hypothesis have not been proven, we do not know what is going on with our climate, which they fail to say when making such claims. The government funded studies also claim the sun not playing a major role in our climate. I’m no scientist by any means, but that just seems ludicrous to say given that the sun literally affects everything here on earth. To me, the sun having major affects on our weather AND climate, just seems like logical common sense. But their climate prediction models show little if no interference by the sun. This is a HUGE problem with the hypothesis of human activities being the main driver of our climate. Once the models include the sun being a bigger driver to our climate over human activity, then we will finally see the true state of our climate and what it means going forward. We have a mediocre understanding of our sun and it’s cycles, but we know more about our sun than our climate, that’s for sure.

text:
I wish I could teach Knowles about the hydrologic cycle in my environmental science class (and no, not environmentalism).

Let’s talk about water...an invaluable resource that is the sustenance of all biological life. 

Climate change (both anthropogenic and natural) have been shown to make weather behaviors more erratic. 
Over many decades, NASA Earth Observatory data depicts the increasing in severity and frequency of droughts. We all know the effects of droughts and how it can significantly impact agriculture and industry.

Also, consider the many other problems that climate change can instigate. One of the most obvious being sea-level rise. Not only will this cause economic stress to the infrastructures of urbanized cities on coastlines, but it will also affect the availability and accessibility of freshwater. Salt water intrusion into freshwater aquifers is another issue that you can thank sea-level rise for.
Just so you understand how this works: the warmer the Earth is, the less ice will form during winters, which means less melt in the summers. Humanity relies on much of that glacial melt to produce freshwater in order to meet yearly demand on agricultural and industrial services that compose much of the economies around the world. 

If climate change doesn’t concern you now, it will once humans starts pricing water at a higher value. When the effects of climate change hinder the access to a vital resource like freshwater, not only will it hurt economies, but the desperation will produce breeding grounds for radical ideologies, terrorism, and violence.

Even if you don’t agree with anything I said, let’s say this issue is true. What should be done about this?

text: With all due respect, my grandfather and I continue to have these debates, him arguing a point much like yours, and I'd like to point out some evidence that often gets overlooked. Yes, weather changes from year to year because of many cycles including ocean currents and wind patterns, but this is not the same as the orbital cycles that actually change the solar influx that the earth is receiving. What I hear so often is that "the earth is just coming out of an ice age and warming like it has in the past" which is actually probably true, the thing that people don't realize is that we shouldn't be seeing the warming trends that we do, because these cycles happen SO VERY slowly. The changes in the earths orbit that lead to ice ages and warmer periods are called Milankovitch Cycles (look them up!) and they occur over tens of THOUSANDS, even hundreds of thousands of years! Though there is much more to be said on this; the fact is that data collected over 100 years is short-term compared to these cycles. Attributing the warming we are seeing now to these cycles shows a lack of understanding of how slowly warming would be occurring if it was truly "just like it was in the past". There are most definitely other aspects at play and there's a lot of science to back that up as well.

text:
@Paul Heffner  I appreciate your take on things as you see it today! But there is also EVIDENCE Paul (if I may call you by your first name), the records don't show everything. When I was doing research for a book I was writing, I had to delve deep into ACTUAL church records and many decades ago anything important would be recorded in church records over many many hundreds of years. I wanted to see if there'd been any disasters etc in villages and surrounding villages, in certain places (not all towns and cities) had things like flyers (as we call them today) but church records were used mainly. There, right in front of my eyes in the early 1600's, was a two page account of a massive storm that had taken stone buildings out, torn down stone bridges and uprooted dozens of huge oak trees etc, many people had lost their lives and it gave a list. 
I started to look for information in other places where you would have thought, something as serious as this, would have been recorded and it was NOT, not anywhere to be found. I delved really deep into the parish records at the main record office, still nothing to be found. As I continued with the research that I'd started to look for, there again, I was confronted with a full account of there being an extremely hot summer 2 yrs later after the storm! Again, many young and old had lost their lives because of it... Much as we are warned today of what can happen in extreme hot weather! To only find the information in a church Baptism book and no info about these two incidents (not even in the records in London where all documents/information has been copied and archived), proves that not all information was recorded in the so called accounts that places like the Met office would have on their records or those they use for past events, I know I've checked them out for the info I needed as mentioned above! 

Then, my own grandmother who was 100 when I was asked her questions on the subject (she passed aged 104 in 2004 still sharp as a whistle) I'd asked her if she'd known anything about it as it had taken place in the area where she'd been born and lived all her life and she said she knew nothing about it, but she then went on to say that, as far back as she could remember and she could remember back to being 5, the weather changed like this all the time... She remembered extreme hot summers and knee/thigh deep snowy winters and then mild YEARS with neither weather as just mentioned... So our yearly cycles are within a cycle and yes, we've had hot tropical weather for years, the cliff strata tells you this... and we've also had mini ice ages for many years, as you mentioned in the  Milankovitch Cycles, and we'll continue to have these cycles for many millennia to come. 
It maddens me when reporters report on HOW BAD THE WEATHER IS GETTING along the coastal areas, as they show buildings dropping over the cliffs... What they don't say, is nothing about folk BUILDING TOO NEAR THEM, KNOWING THAT THE CLIFFS ARE PRONE TO COLLAPSING, whether that be slow or not, these builders must do their research and see that over the past 30yrs the land has fallen into the sea by at least 3 miles when they started to record it, but they make the story so dramatic and call it Climate change, it is not, most cliff faces like the one at Scarborough are built on soft soils, (The cliff consists of Glacial Till (sandy, silty clay) resting on a low cliff of the Middle Jurassic Scalby Formation. The Scalby Formation comprises Scalby Mudstone and Moor Grit (sandstone). So anyone with an ounce of sense knows that water hitting soft sediments  will eventually WEAR IT AWAY, that does not mean that it's anything to do with the climate. The UK is surrounded by water and 30 years ago, there had been 3 miles more of land at Scarborough than there is today, it has simply been washed away because of its strata, soft soil... It will continue to wash away until the water hits solid rock, which will still wear away, but at a much slower pace! 

Most people today, well those under the age of 35, see more than an inch of snow and the country stops, while us oldies sit back in shock because we've seen it like it before. It beggars belief that we can get strong winds and according to the young ones the world is going to end, we get a storm and the world is going to end, we get a hot summer and the world is going to end! No it's not, it will go on as it always has done! Some times you have to STOP taking in what you see on the TV screen as they've been caught out lying. Making things seem far worse than they actually are... 
Take CNN,  They recorded a storm last year, they put it out about how bad the storm was, but what the idiot reporter didn't see was when they televised the clip, there right at the top of the screen in the background were a couple walking normal away from the camera! What they'd done to make it look like the reporter was about to blown over, was to have a blow machine at the side out of view and turned on high, making it look like the reporter could hardly stand up! It was so fake but the report had many folk frightened in the beginning until they saw what they'd done to BRAINWASH the public. We know for a fact that some things we see on TV are not what they look like and some things are done on purpose to FRIGHTEN THE PUBLIC!

text: The "problem" with climate change, or environmental disaster threats to human civilisation and the planet is not whether its real or not.  The problem is since Al Gore the RISK and repercussions of climate disaster to our global societies has been taken over by politicians and used as a platform.  This one factor, although drawing public attention to what 90% of scientists now agree, is the reason for inaction.  Politicians want to govern society for economic financial reasons, and that is the bottom line.  There is only one way forward if you have enough intelligence and survival resilience, is to research for yourself the reality and impacts of climate change—whether human caused or not—you don't have to watch it on TV in documentaries that you think are propaganda.  You might live in California and have suffered wild fires, or Australia for that matter.  Or you might live on an island in the pacific or Miami, that is rapidly drowning.  Governments ARE acting for the climate changes - because it is the biggest impact to our economic wealth that we as a species are facing.  But do we as individuals survive by waiting for governments to tell us it is real or not - whether left, right or out the door?  How adaptive and resilient is that?  If we individually believe that this is a greater threat to our livelihoods, jobs and children than who we vote for to tell us how to effectively run our countries- we must take action for ourselves—at grass roots—find the truth and take community actions.  When Gandhi led 200 million people to freedom, the Bengal famine wasn't "real" either.  That was because Winston Churchill and the first world empire were fighting a war against Germany and Japan and wanted India's men and food resources for their own cause.  Thirty million people died in that famine - mostly invisibly because it was a third world country.  Individually you can't sign the Paris agreement or order corporations to stop carbon emissions.  But there are other actions you can take towards greening your community and adaptive resilience in the face of what we do know is a fact:  the Earth climate is rapidly changing and humans are facing massive environmental threats wherever they live.  Happy voting.

text:
The issue with depicting certanties around climate change is due to the amount of variables at play. Collective data can be misconstrude, as there are other subjective parameters surrounding, already, subjective variables. However, one issue I have with Michael Knowles ideals, may be explained in the form of an analogy that addresses this matter with more clarity. Although, Michael seems very neutral on this matter, in all fairness. The analogy would be as follows. 

Separate a shopping list, although some products may have sale offers and others may not. We can differentiate these subjects, by sale offers, representing  consistencies in climate, thus no or very little change is made annually. Yet, associate normal/regular prices to be inadequecies within climate change. 

We all shop for the cheapest thing, however, we have to resort to buying products at normal prices. Sometimes these products may be on offer. However, we are never to know when products will have an offer on them. The one thing that stays consistent, is that we purchase the product, thus our shopping total fluctuates. Subsequently, if none of the products are on sale though, then the original value will increase the overall expenditure. Thus climate change can be thought of on these principles. It is an accumulative effect.

text:
Pending Ice Age, Anthropogenic Global Warming, Climate Change - all claim Human-contributed CO2 is causing heating of the atmosphere to unsustainable levels.

But CO2 is < 5% of Earth's Greehouse gas, Humans contribute about 5% of that CO2, and the eRt (basically, energy retention capacity) of CO2 is 3.6%.

Water Vapor .. is from 70 to over 90% of Earth's Greenhouse gas at any given time, Humans contribute up to 11% of that, and it has an eRT of over 80%.

So anyone claiming to be a scientist, or to have any scientific credentials, needs to explain foremost why they are more concerned with CO2 (0.05 * 0.05 * 0.036) than water vapor (0.7 * 0.11 * 0.8).
... particularly when reducing our water vapor contribution by Half would be no more invasive than mandating condensers on manufacturing that produces it as a bi-product - essentially a re-purposed refrigerator for every roughly 10,000 gallons of water produced/year as vapor.

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

text: Climate change has been going on since the beginning of time.  A geologist, of all scientists, should understand the reality of how such things can take hundreds of years or more. We are not God, we are only stewards of what we’ve been given to work with on this dear planet.  To be good stewards does not equate to being able to control the natural order of the earth.  How else would one explain the ice age or its subsequent passing?  Mankind certainly wasn’t the cause of that massive climate change, or flatulent dinosaurs, or any other living organism of the time.  This panic over this subject is misplaced and misinformed.  All one has to do is look back over the history of eons and see that, much like spring, summer, fall and winter, climate changes over long periods of time worldwide.

In the last 300 years global temperature has risen 1 degree Celsius, while co2 levels rose from 295 to 383 parts per million. That means that 88 parts per million gives a 1 degree Celsius increase in temperature. So to find out what temperature we would get with a pure co2 atmosphere we can divide 1 million by 90 (rounding up 88 for convenience) to get 11,111. If your bullshit detector hasn't gone off you are a socialist idiot. If you think an increase of over 11,100 degree Celsius is a bad result you are not seeing the trees for the forest. I would file a patent for a "Carbon dioxide charged solar energy collector." and become the richest being on the planet. It will not work because co2 does not cause climate change. Before you waste your money on patents do the following experiment. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gKB7RWXOEpw And study the Beer-Lambert-Bouguer law from 1852. 
Show less

text:
My dad was a geologist who worked building the great dams of the North West. He moved us away from the volcanoes and was not surprised when Mount Saint Helens blew even though supposedly everybody else was. He told us kids not to be worried about climate change that the world was warming up as it was supposed to and had been for the last 100 years that recycling was a good thing because he grew up doing it during the depression and that you shouldn't waste anything but he told us that the government and people will try to have you look one way & not be afraid of what's really happening. He told us the world is going to get warmer. It's not going to be like it was for the last 500 years where, unfortunately, we built all of our cities next to the ocean, just like the people before us 10000 years ago, and then they got flooded when, poof! ocean rose 400 feet. 

He showed us how the Earth cycles & sadly modern man in his hubris thinks his science will control all things. But when you speak with the Native Americans, listen to their history, those that knew the history of their area, you got a different story. That a great cold had come over the land 600 years before and had frozen the sleeping giants (volcanoes), changed their world.  Now it was lessening its hold, and things are becoming warm again, where it hadn't been warm for many turns of the sun. 
Like my father said, it's easier to make people look at something they think they can control instead of trying to teach them about something there's nothing they can do about. 

 In Puyallup, WA they now have volcano evacuation drills. We never had them when I was a kid, but they're very serious about it. Some of the hot springs are closed in Mammoth, CA, they lost 3 Ski Patrol members when they were trying to put temporary fencing around an open vent &  died from toxic fumes. 
 
There was an earthquake in Big Bear Lake CA when there had never been knowledge of any fault line running near it. Previously there'd been geological testing looking for one. The one place everybody thought they'd be ok, no one had any earthquake insurance. The storms are getting worse in the Atlantic, coming onto land, causing greater devastation. Tornados are touching down stronger, larger & in strange places. The world is going back to the weather pattern it had before the freeze. Modern man doesn't know what that is.

Switzerland will know, because they have a record of it, maybe some of the other countries, if they're able to dig up any of their old records. Maybe their history will tell them. The Americas that is going to be a big question. 

Africa will be changed too because they will no longer have the dirty smoke from the British Isles to help them  obtain rain. Like my dad said,  clean air doesn't help keep the earth cool, so we can obtain rain.  

Maybe the volcanoes waking up again will help us out, but we really didn't want that because their product is more toxic & causes problems with our machines. The world is going to be an interesting place, it will be more like it was before Christopher Columbus set out to find the New World. 

When one thinks about the fact the people settling at Roanoke came to the New World in one of the worst times of drought. It'll be interesting to see how we fair. The Arctic will open like it was before the Northwest Passage won't be clogged with ice but the loss of ice means possibly pristine seabed destroyed by oil drilling etc. A new responsibility.

Hi Brian Schaefer, I do not have the answer to all your questions but debating with people is something that I enjoy. First of all, I am not really into politics so I  will not attack or support any party, I am just a young scientist that wants to share something that he learned. 

1) Humans do contribute to climate change. 
We humans directly participate in air pollution and air pollution has a lot to do with global warming. Let's use a quantum mechanics perspective. We would not talk about sunlight but energy and radiation. The Earth´s atmosphere has natural CO2 levels which help to keep the planet warm. The sunlight is made of photons (radiation) which after hitting the Earth´s surface go back to space and there is when CO2 acts. Now we will consider the molecular level. The photons hit the CO2 molecules which excite the electrons in the CO2 and therefore they have a higher energy level. In nature, molecules do not like to be in a high energy level, they prefer to be stable or in a low energy level, so the excited electron goes back to its original energy level sending a new photon to the Earth (energy/radiation). This is more or less how CO2 helps to keep the planet warm (I'm not a physicist, but I took college-level courses and like to know about cool stuff). Now, If we have more CO2 levels in the air (directly related to air pollution), more CO2 molecules would keep more photons (radiation) in the atmosphere and radiation is responsible for keeping the Earth warm. Now, there are records that suggest that since the industrial revolution, CO2 levels in the air have arisen due to human activities. What is really interesting is that sunlight is not the only radiations that contribute to this process. The Earth itself emits radiation from its nucleus causing CO2 to emit photons that would also contribute to Earth´s temperature. So yeah, both are connected, air pollutions can lead to global warming.

2) I guess that the answer would depend on who you ask, let me explain myself. I remember that I saw a video on youtube from an organization that makes videos about politics and they were discussing whether or not climate change was as bad as people suggest. They did not deny climate change but suggested that it wasn´t that bad because there were just a few deads related to events caused by climate change. They might be right, perhaps people are not dying because of climate but in my personal opinion, they failed to address the problems that animals and nature are facing because of climate change. The is no doubt that the Antartic ice is melting because of the increasing temperatures which have had a negative impact on the animals inhabiting that area. At the same time, other natural ecosystems have been affected by climate change resulting in animals struggling with these harsh conditions and of course, dying. So in my opinion, even though humans might no be directly dying because of climate change, it has a negative impact on animals and nature. and for me, it is something to worry about. 

This is all that I have, I don´t have answers for the last two questions, I am just a Neuroscientist. It is your decision what to think about this topic, I personally believe that it is something very important to consider, so let me know what you think. I apologies if I made grammar mistakes, English is not my first language, but I try my best.

text:
The problem is way more nuanced than extremists on the left paint it.  In order to avoid being screamed at and called "Hitler", you have to believe ALL of these things, in this order:
1 - The earth is warming
2 - The earth is warming outside of its normal hot-to-cold-to-hot-to-cold rhythm
3 - That people are the dominant reason for this break in the normal cycle
4 - That people can do something about this break in the cycle
5 - That the government should be in charge of forcing people to do something about this break in the cycle by:
6 - Increasing taxes on certain activities
7 - Then by taking the revenue from those increased taxes and giving it to certain other people

If you fail to believe any one of those things, then you're immediately labeled a "denier", and you're a socio-political outcast from all future conversations, and they use the bully-pulpit as defined by their level of outrage, to show their moral stance as superior to your own.  If you don't flip out, then you don't care, AND, you're therefore less moral.

Added to this are the plot-holes that you're supposed to ignore:
1 - The US can do absolutely everything as suggested by the most extreme "green plan", and it still would have no effect on what China, India, Mexico, Iran, Etc, do.
2 - There have been countless predictions of what the climate would be by now, and not a single one of them have come true.

actually in the 1970's we were being told we were heading for another ice age, leonard nimoy did a voice over on a documentary about it back then, they were concerned the earth was cooling, then we got global warming in the late 80's, now its climate change, they changed it because the temperatures have some what stabilized, almost every prediction made by certain figures has so far not come true, it was said that by 2012, the ice caps would have melted and florida would be under water, that has not happened, they claimed sea levels would rise yet where i live the evidence is that there is no level rise, venice has seen no level rise and neither has miami, the claims made by climate proponents have been shot around for decades including the % of scientists that are supposed to agree with the scientific claims, 99%, but that isn't true either.

now i'm not saying something isn't going on, there is most definitely, but to claim humans are to blame is preposterous when you actually look at the numbers, CO2 makes up around 0.04% of our atmosphere and humans are responsible for around 1% of the 0.04%, oh they like to throw out these huge numbers, saying humans put this or that many tons of CO2 into the atmosphere in this or that year but they dont give you the percentage of our contribution compared to the natural sources, when you think about the fact that man is only responsible for 1% of 0.04% of the CO2 in the atmosphere it kind of puts a different perspective on that doesnt it, especially when you think that we actually produce less CO2 now than we did during the industrial revolution.

i have an alternative proposition for the changes that actually has science to back it up too, our magnetosphere has been getting weaker over the last couple of hundred years, that weakening has increased over the last 20 years, now the magnetosphere is created by the rotation of the earths core and the outer crusts rotation is a direct result of the cores rotation, bare with me you will get the picture soon, now the global temperatures over the last 2-3 years has stabilized, at the exact time that earths rotation actually sped up, now a weakening magnetosphere means more solar radiation reaching the surface which warms the planet and drives climate, this is not new information by the way, scientists have known about the magnetosphere for decades and how it was weakening, so it begs the question, why are they so quiet about it? why is that not being pushed as the narrative for the cause of climate change? could it be that they have yet to figure out how to make money from it? or could it be that they know nothing can be done about it and letting people know the truth might cause panic? or could it be a mix of all the above?

text: @lee smith  have you seen the recent results on comic rays causing cloud cover - the ECS for comic rays is ~ 4.  Using this effect in the GCM eliminates the assumed CO2 ECS and produces more accurate predictions of global temperature. The assumed feedback of CO2 causing increased humidity has also been shown invalid - the net effect of increased humidity due to increased CO2 is an evaporative cooing effect - reducing the ECS for CO2 to less than 1.

      "The most dramatically impacted country was St. Kitts and Nevis in the Caribbean, which has shrunk approximately 34.7 square miles, more than a quarter of its land area, since 1961. Ecuador came next with a loss of 10.29 percent of its land area, at approximately 10,996.2 square miles. Vietnam was third with a loss of 4.74 percent of its total area." ~Ecowatch.com, Olivia Rosane.
If you do some independent searching, you'll find how much of an impact "climate change" has. And that's just rising sea levels. That's just the Greenland Ice Sheet. text:
YAFTV, you said in the description, "Even if 'climate change' were a real, man-made, and urgent problem..." Climate change has always been real. That is climate's one constant -- change! Urgent? We have minor warming in an Ice Age that produces the most prosperous period in human history, and someone calls that dangerous? Holocene has had 10 major warm periods, once every thousand years or so, and the Modern shows up right on schedule (natural), but is the coldest of the 10 (wimpy CO2, so hardly attributable to man, even a tiny percentage).

It's like the Warming Alarmist Globalist-Leftists have a beef with prosperity and life. In fact, they are the #ProDeath Cult -- pushing COOLING in an ongoing Ice Age, abortion (baby murder), euthanasia, eugenics and more. The Left is the side of tyranny and lies -- 100% government, 0% freedom.

text:
@Daniel  so i take it you didn't pay any attention in high school. Scientists can say how old something that used to be alive is with carbon dating. If they find fossils from big tropical trees in the Arctic they carbon date them and find out how many years ago there were tropical trees in the Arctic, which means that the climate in the artic was tropical x years ago. If they find remains of hairy mammals in Africa they carbon date them and come to the conclusion that it was cold in africa ω years ago. They also study the ground. Thats literally what the entire field of the science of geology does. Scientists know that every 1000 years the ground rises by a few centimetres. So they dig the earth grab a piece and study it's layers. Based on the layers and on how deep they dug to grab that piece they say that on that region x years ago there was an ocean or there was a lot of volcanic activity etc.
That's how scientists know that 56 million year ago the earth was warmer than it is now, there were tropical trees all the way to the north pole and there was barely any life in the oceans at that period. I learned all that at grade's 8 geography. But then again i went to high school.

author: Mavic Pro

text: @Dennis Walker  Sorry to tell but CO2 plays a critical role in keeping the temperature in the Earth. Let's use a quantum mechanics perspective. We would not talk about sunlight but energy and radiation. The Earth´s atmosphere has natural CO2 levels which help to keep the planet warm. The sunlight is made of photons (radiation) which after hitting the Earth´s surface go back to space and there is when CO2 acts. Now we will consider the molecular level. The photons hit the CO2 molecules which excite the electrons in the CO2 and therefore they have a higher energy level. In nature, molecules do not like to be in a high energy level, they prefer to be stable or in a low energy level, so the excited electron goes back to its original energy level sending a new photon to the Earth (energy/radiation). This is more or less how CO2 helps to keep the planet warm (I'm not a physicist, but I took college-level courses and like to know about cool stuff). Now, If we have more CO2 levels in the air (directly related to air pollution), more CO2 molecules would keep more photons (radiation) in the atmosphere and radiation is responsible for keeping the Earth warm. Now, there are records from the American Chemical Society that suggest that since the industrial revolution, CO2 levels in the air have arisen due to human activities. What is really interesting is that sunlight is not the only radiation that contributes to this process. The Earth itself emits radiation from its nucleus causing CO2 to emit photons that would also contribute to Earth´s temperature.
author: Luis Aguilera Luna

text: @Mavic Pro    perhaps CO2 levels were over 5 times higher than now in the Jurassic Period as you mentioned, but that doesn´t mean that the current living species can survive those conditions. Let´s use another example, before the Earth´s atmosphere had the current oxygen levels, there was plenty of life in the oceans, many organisms lived at that time and used methane to live. However, when a specific bacteria that used sunlight as a source of energy starts to fill out the air with oxygen, many species started to die, because oxygen was poison for them. This is known as one of the 5 greatest extinction in the Earth´s history, around 90% of the species vanished. What I am trying to say it is that even in previous times CO2 levels were higher and life was plentiful, those organisms were used to those conditions, and we are not. Could something similar happen to us? I don´t know, but it is something to consider when we know the history of the Earth.
author: Luis Aguilera Luna

text: ​ @Dennis Walker  it is a fair argument, the Earth´s temperature hasn´t increased drastically in the previous decades. Just to be clear, I don´t live in the US, so I do not support any political party. That being said I do not know what US politicians have said about climate change. However, I am talking about events scientifically proved, you can go and read books about quantum mechanics and molecular orbitals and you would realize that what I just explained happens, so yeah, CO2 does participate in Earth´s temperature (we actually need it, without CO2 the Earth might drastically change is temperature), something that you denied. How much CO2 actually contribute to climate change? I don´t know, but you can be sure that it does affect the Earth´s temperature, as I said, try to read about how it works, and you will find out that there is no doubt that CO2 affects the temperature.
author: Luis Aguilera Luna

text: ​ @Dennis Walker  certainly I do not have the right answer to your question, I am not an expert on this topic. I do believe that CO2 levels contribute to increasing the temperature, how much does CO2 contribute? I don´t know, maybe it does has a small contribution, but still, contribute to the Earth´s temperature, at the end of the day that is what greenhouses gases do, help to keep the temperature that allows life on Earth. According to the phenomenon that I explained in the previous comment, I would imagine that CO2 increase leads to temperature increase, and also if you see the graphs that measure the CO2 levels and Earth´s temperature since the industrial revolution both have increased during that time. It is true that the Earth´s temperature hasn´t increased that much (around 1 Celcius degree) during that time but at the same time, the temperature hasn´t gone back to its original level as before the industrial revolution.  There are fluctuations, as in every experiment, but still, the graphs show an increasing behavior. I am not telling you that we would have catastrophic consequences in a few years, I am not qualified to make that assumption, but you cannot deny the correlated increasing behavior, even though it could have a small contribution. Another interesting thing to consider, which I don´t know, is how much nature has been affected by the increasing temperature since the industrial revolutions, in that way, we would be able to know if one-degree increase is something to worry about, but I have zero information about this
author: Luis Aguilera Luna

text: @Dennis Walker  ​  hey!! I don't know if you might be interested, but while I was watching a documentary (Cosmos, not really about the environment but they discuss a little bit) they mentioned that from the different Greenhouse gases, Methane has a greater impact on Earth's temperature than CO2, but of course, we have directly changed the CO2 concentration, not the Methane concentration. This made me wonder if every gas has a different contribution to Earth's temperature, that could explain why the Earth's temperature hasn't increased that much in contrast to CO2 concentration. Let us try to use a simple equation just to explain this, imagine that the Earth's temperature is represented by T= 0.5H20 + 2.4CH4 + 1.5N2O + 1.3CO2 + 1.0 O3 (not a real equation) where H2O is water, CH4 is methane, N2O is nitrous oxide, CO2 is carbon dioxide and O3 ozone. As we can see, each gas has a different contribution and the combination of all of them states the Earth's temperature and because CO2 is not the one with the highest contribution, it would take higher CO2 levels to drastically change the Earth's temperature, which could explain why the Earth's temperature hasn't changed that much in contrast with the CO2 levels, because CO2 is not the only variable in the equation, and because is not the one with the highest contribution. However, the amount of CO2 levels continues to increase, which could, in the future, increase the Earth's temperature. This is a hypothetical case, I don't really know the equation that explains the temperature behavior, but I found if very interesting. As for the Earth's temperature, I found that the average Earth' temperature is about 15 Celcius degrees, with the industrial revolution, if the Earth's temperature increased about 1 Celcius degree since the industrial revolution, that means that the Earth's temperature increased around 7% of its original temperature during the same period, it would be interesting to know how much did it change before the industrial revolution in a similar time period. Again, I am not an expert on this topic, but it is interesting, let me know what do you think.
author: Luis Aguilera Luna

text: ​ @Dennis Walker  I do agree with you in different things. The Earth's temperature has always changed regardless of human activity. Scientists have made mispredictions and have failed to address certain concerns. And changing the world's economy will, of course, have a huge impact. However, if scientists do not speak out about this topic, who else can? maybe it is because I am a scientist myself (Neuroscience graduate student), but taking in consideration the experts' opinions is the smartest thing that you can do and not just what politicians have to say. yeah, you always have to question everything when talking about such delicate topic like changing the world's economy, but also they have succeeded in predicting certain things. For example, during the first part of the last century, a US scientist stated that just a small change in the Earth's temperature (a few degrees) would be enough to melt the Antartic ice, which it is actually happening. At the same time, according to Neil Degrasse Tyson, the Earth's temperature increased more or less as scientists predicted. Finally, I guess that neither of us can change each other opinion about the impact of CO2 levels, but I do believe it has something to do with climate change, as many scientists (people that actually study this) do. If it has been proved that Greenhouse gases play a critical role in Earth's temperature (for good or bad), and there is no doubt that human activity influents the amount of at least one of those gases, for sure humans contribute to climate change in a certain way. Something interesting to ask would be, so if you don't believe that reducing the activities (not avoid them) that produce CO2 it is the best decision, what would be?

text: Was that Ash Heap in California, or Australia by any chance?  Some years ago I was living in rural Australia and with the Volunteer Fire Brigade.  We had the data on climate change, we knew even at community level from the scientific experts who visited our communities and talked to us about the increasing threat coming from planetary warming (whatever its cause).  We were told to prepare by teaching communities what the threats and dangers were living.  We were told to back burn and clear because the increasing hot summers (which have arrived and continue) would result in an insurmountable tinder bed of dry undergrowth.  And that's what fire brigades systematically did.  But we were also told that it would be impossible to back burn and clear enough to prevent the massive fires and heat storms that will come.  After the Victorian fire took all those lives we were also advised the new dangers of those fleeing the raised heat and impacts of those fires - the people who died sheltering on football fields because of the wall of heat that reached them and those who died in underground bunkers for example.  Yes, traditional survival actions that didn't work.  Our government changed the laws, educated people and regulated people about building in bush clad areas—but still they warned us that even these "minimal" actions would not be enough for when the planet truly hotted up.  In 2015, 2016, 2018 and then 2019 their PREDICTIONS CAME TRUE.  AUSTRALIA BURNED IN AN ASH HEAP.  Billions of plants and animal species were lost along with humans.  HAVE A NICE DAY IN YOUR CORONA VIRUS PROOF SOCIETY - another example of political platforms that failed for financial economic reasons.

text:
PowWowChicken actually dude China has gotten so rich that they are switching to renewables and are less of a problem. The US is second in pollution only to India now. China is better than you guys. Think about that for a second. 

Also the facts are clear the Artic has 40% less sea ice now in summer than it did in 1980. Tell me the planet isn’t getting warmer. It is a fact that climate change is real. However I believe in a free market solution. You have been duped by some idiots on the right to think it isn’t a problem. It is. What we should be fighting is for free market solutions over idiots like AOC and her socialist cronies. 

Have a look at Nori.com it is a company that is providing said free market solutions to fixing climate change. 

As for planting trees, great, we are planting more trees now than we did before. Unless what we planted before was exceptionally high that is a crap statistic. What you need to focus on is the fact that vast swathes of the Amazon rainforest is being demolished. That is a big problem.
